item.title: Docs: Home Monitoring System - HOMS
item.description:
Potala Home Monitoring system, HOMS, is a home monitoring system with AI-based object recognition.

Potala Home Monitoring system can be configured to capture image frame based on two different modes: manual, or motion triggerred. Captured images are processed in offline batch mode for recognizing object(s) in the picture. There is an additional mode that capture images, also based on motion triggered, and process object recognition inline albeit it is slower.

Outdoor Cameras.
Photo: pexels.com

Prerequisites

  • Raspberry Pi 3 Model B+, or Pi 4 Model

  • Picamera Module v2.1, Sony IMX219 8-megapixel sensor

  • [Optional] USB storage: flash drive, SSD drive, or hard drive

Functional Overview

The high level functional setup of the home monitoring system is illustrated below.

Functional Setup
Photo: Dzong

The hardware components consists of: Raspberry Pi, and the Pi camera. It’s assumed that the RPi is connected to a monitor, keyboard and mouse, at least during initial setup; they can be removed after completion of the setup. Future access to RPi can be done using SSH for terminal access, and VNC for GUI access. Both of these services need to be enabled because they are not enabled by default. Please refer to Remote Access - SSH and Remote Access - VNC for how to enable these services.

The software components (services) consists of:

  • Image web portal to view and review captured images

  • Camera monitoring services

Hardware Setup

It’s amazing what a low-cost single board computer like Raspberry Pi can do. This is based on the Pi 3 Model B+. The Pi 4 and future models will get even better.

Raspberry Pi 3 Model B+ mounted on the back of 7-inch capacitive touch screen.
Photo: Dzong

Complete setup of Raspberry Pi with Pi-camera
Photo: Dzong

A similar setup running Nvidia Jetson Nano connected to Dell P2210 (22-inch wide screen) running Potala applications using the GPU.

Complete setup Nvidia Jetson Nano with Pi-camera
Photo: Dzong

Software Installation and Setup

The installation and setup can be found at:

  • Potala Home Monitoring System for Raspberry Pi @Github.

  • Potala Home Monitoring System for Jetson Nano @Github.

Deployed @Home

Depending where you place the camera or the type of camera used, the results can be pretty impressive.

Web-based Image Portal
Photo: Dzong

item.title: Docs: Raspberry Pi
item.description:
Raspberry Pi is a single board computer based on Cortex-A72 (ARM v8) 64-bit Quad core. The latest version is Raspberry Pi 4 but the below instructions are based on raspberry Pi 3 Model B+.

Prerequisites

  • Raspberry Pi 3 Model B+, or Pi 4 Model

  • Picamera Module v2.1, Sony IMX219 8-megapixel sensor

  • [Optional] USB storage: flash drive, SSD drive, or hard drive

Installation

If you are not familiar with Raspberry Pi (RPi), please visit Getting started with Raspberry Pi to get acquaintance with your small computer.

We have tested Potala on Raspbian OS stretch and buster. If your RPi has older version, please follow the following instructions to upgrade the OS. Ideally, you should erase and install a fresh OS on the micro SD card. However, if you are an adventurer please follow the official guidelines, Updating and upgrading Raspbian.

To clean install the latest Raspbian OS:

  • From a computer or laptop, download the Raspbian OS from Raspberry Pi download

    • Select “Raspbian“
    • Choose the “desktop” version; for example, “Raspbian Buster with desktop”. We are using the desktop version that comes with the GUI, so to demonstrate the camera streaming on the monitor connected with HDMI cable.
      Otherwsie, Potala will work with the “Lite” version as well, for example, “Raspbian Buster Lite”
    • Click “Download ZIP”
    • For earlier version, Raspbian Stretch, go to downloads archive

  • From the computer and use the downloaded .zip file, install a Raspberry Pi operating system image on an SD card; also described in Installing operating system images:

    • check the SD card requirements but if your SD card is not greater than 32GB, you should be OK to proceed
    • Download balenaEtcher and install on your computer; balenaEtcher is a graphical tool to install OS to SD card that works on Mac OS, Linux and Windows.
    • Insert the SD card into the corresponding slot on your computer
    • Follow the Installing operating system images

  • While the SD card is being flashed, prepare your Raspberry Pi BUT don’t connect the power supply yet. Connect the HDMI cable to a monitor, mouse & keyboard to USB port, get the wifi SSID and password ready, and setup the camera. For instructions on how to setup the camera, please visit Getting started with the Camera Module.

  • When the SD card is flashed, eject from computer & insert it into the Raspberry Pi to start first booting.

  • Continue to the next step, “Setup Raspberry Pi”

Setup Raspberry Pi

  • After first boot, follow the screen instructions to setup the OS; Note: please use the default userid, pi.

  • Login using the login id/password you provided during OS setup, a step above. The default login id: pi; and password: raspberry.

  • If any of the setup is incorrect, reconfigure using raspi-config from terminal, setup that includes: change password, setup country, language, timezone, keyboard, wifi, etc.

    sudo raspi-config

    Note: to reconfigure using GUI, go to Start - Preference - Raspberry Pi Configuration

  • Assuming you have setup the camera while waiting for the SD to be flashed, proceed with enabling the camera on the next step; otherwise follow the instructions on how to setup the camera, by visiting Getting started with the Camera Module

  • If not already done, enable the camera using 'raspi-config from the terminal, or from the Raspberry Pi Configuration GUI. For more detailed instructions, please visit Connect the Camera Module

  • check if the camera is mounted correctly and working, by opening a terminal and type:

    cd ~
raspistill -v -o test.jpg

    Refer to Raspberry Camera Module

  • Finally, update the raspbian OS to get the latest patches

    sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get dist-upgrade

  • Now your RPi host is ready for AI vision applications

Deploy AI Application

Next, let’s install and setup an AI application to demonstrate DEC Potala in action. Let’s go to AI Solutions.

item.title: Docs: Jetson Nano
item.description:
Nvidia Jetson Nano is based on ARM Cortex A57 CPU that can run both 64bit and 32bit ARM instructions. The Jetson Nano™ Developer Kit refers to both HW and SW, as discussed on Jetson Nano Developer Kit

Prerequisites

  • Nvidia Jetson Nano

  • Picamera Module v2.1, Sony IMX219 8-megapixel sensor

  • [Optional] USB storage: flash drive, SSD drive, or hard drive

Installation

If you are not familiar with Nvidia Jetson Nano, please visit Getting Started With Jetson Nano Developer Kit to get acquainted with your GPU computer. Follow the beginner instructions that includes: introduction, prepare for setup, write image to the microSD card, setup and first boot, next steps, and troubleshooting.

Jetson Nano default Operating System is Ubuntu and it’s bundled in the Jetpack SDK that also contains developer tools, libraries and APIs, samples, and documentation needed to develop AI application using Nvidia CUDA.

[Recommended] the instruction on the Getting Started With Jetson Nano Developer Kit - Write Image to the microSD Card step, asks to download the SD Card image in zip file by cliking on the link on step 1. Download the Jetson Nano Developer Kit SD Card Image. NOTE: the link may point to an old version file. As of this writing, the latest version file is jetson-nano-sd-r32.2.1.zip which contains to Jetpack version 4.2.2, and can be downloaded from: https://developer.nvidia.com/embedded/jetpack

Also note that there are two ways of flashing (a.k.a, installing OS on Jetson Nano):

  • Recommended - download the SD Card image to a computer or laptop, and flash the image to the SD card using, for example, Etcher. The SD Card image is refered by NVIDIA as JetPack SDK and the latest version as of this writing is version 4.2.2. NOTE: using version 4.2.1 or later is important because version 4.2.1 or later includes a beta version of NVIDIA Container Runtime with Docker integration for the Jetson platform.

  • The second way to setup OS on Jetson Nano is to use the NVIDIA SDK Manager; this method also need to be perform from a computer/laptop, but it seems to be more complicated and involves SDK Manager GUI. Has not been attempted.

Step-by-step instructions

  • From a computer or laptop, if not already downloaded, go to https://developer.nvidia.com/embedded/jetpack and download the latest version of Jetpack version 4.2.2. As of this writing, the latest version file is jetson-nano-sd-r32.2.1.zip which contains to Jetpack version 4.2.2. Therefore, the following instructions are based on version 4.2.2.

  • From the computer and use the downloaded .zip file, install the operating system image on an SD card. The steps are exactly the same as the Raspberry Pi as described in Installing operating system images:

    • check the SD card requirements but if your SD card is not greater than 32GB, you should be OK to proceed
    • Download balenaEtcher and install on your computer; balenaEtcher is a graphical tool to install OS to SD card that works on Mac OS, Linux and Windows.
    • Insert the SD card into the corresponding slot on your computer
    • Follow the Installing operating system images

  • While the SD card is being flashed, prepare your Jetson Nano BUT don’t connect the power supply yet. Connect the HDMI cable to a monitor, mouse & keyboard to USB port, get the wifi SSID and password ready, and setup the camera. For instructions on how to connect the Pi-camera, please visit Jetson Nano + Raspberry Pi Camera. USB camera will be discussed in the future.

  • When the SD card is flashed, eject from computer & insert it into the Jetson Nano to start first booting. In case you can’t find where the micro SD card port is, go to Getting Started With Jetson Nano Developer Kit - Setup and First Boot

  • Continue to the next step, “Setup Jetson Nano”

Setup Jetson Nano

  • After first boot, follow the screen instructions to setup the OS

  • Login using the login id/password you provided during OS setup, a step above. It’s important to use the login id, pi, for the preconfigured scripts to work later.

  • Check kernel version for your own info

    uname -a 
Linux pi-desktop 4.9.140-tegra #1 SMP PREEMPT Wed Mar 13 00:32:22 PDT 2019 aarch64 aarch64 aarch64 GNU/Linux

  • Jetpack 4.2.2 and newer comes preinstalled with NVIDIA Container Runtime; NVIDIA Container Runtime is a GPU aware container runtime, compatible with the Open Containers Initiative (OCI) specification used by Docker, CRI-O, and other popular container technologies. It simplifies the process of building and deploying containerized GPU-accelerated applications. NVIDIA Container Runtime supports container technologies like Docker so developers can wrap their GPU-accelerated applications along with its dependencies into a single package that is guaranteed to deliver the best performance on NVIDIA GPUs, regardless of the deployment environment. It includes a container runtime library and utilities to automatically configure containers to leverage NVIDIA GPUs.

    Ref: https://github.com/nvidia/nvidia-docker/wiki/nvidia-container-runtime-on-jetson

    Nvidia Container Runtime
    Source: Nvidia

  • Check the NVIDIA Container Runtime packages were installed by running:

    sudo dpkg --get-selections | grep nvidia

    Output:

    libnvidia-container-tools			install
libnvidia-container0:arm64			install
nvidia-container-runtime			install
nvidia-container-toolkit			install
nvidia-docker2					install
nvidia-l4t-3d-core				install
nvidia-l4t-apt-source				install
nvidia-l4t-bootloader				install
nvidia-l4t-camera				install
nvidia-l4t-ccp-t210ref				install
nvidia-l4t-configs				install
nvidia-l4t-core					install
nvidia-l4t-cuda					install
nvidia-l4t-firmware				install
nvidia-l4t-graphics-demos			install
nvidia-l4t-gstreamer				install
nvidia-l4t-init					install
nvidia-l4t-kernel				install
nvidia-l4t-kernel-dtbs				install
nvidia-l4t-kernel-headers			install
nvidia-l4t-multimedia				install
nvidia-l4t-multimedia-utils			install
nvidia-l4t-oem-config				install
nvidia-l4t-tools				install
nvidia-l4t-wayland				install
nvidia-l4t-weston				install
nvidia-l4t-x11					install
nvidia-l4t-xusb-firmware			install

  • Check the NVIDIA Container Runtime is installed & running:

    sudo docker info | grep nvidia

    Output:

    Runtimes: nvidia runc

  • Upgrade Docker runtime - JetPack 4.2.2 also comes with docker runtime v18.09.7; However, NVIDIA Container Toolkit needs docker runtime v19.03 or higher, that supports NVIDIA GPUs natively as devices in the Docker runtime. So usage of nvidia-docker2 packages is no longer need and can be deprecated, as discussed in https://github.com/NVIDIA/nvidia-docker#quick-start.

    docker --version
Docker version 18.09.7, build 2d0083d

    Follow official docker instructions at https://docs.docker.com/install/linux/docker-ce/ubuntu/

    • Uninstall docker

      sudo apt-get remove docker docker-engine docker.io containerd runc

    • Install using convenient script

      sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y curl
curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh
sudo sh get-docker.sh

    • to use Docker as a non-root user, adding the user to the “docker” group:

      sudo usermod -aG docker <userID>

      Need to reboot for the command to be active

  • After reboot, check version is correct

    docker --version
Docker version 19.03.2, build 6a30dfc

  • Assuming you have connect the Pi-camera to MIPI-CSI while waiting for the SD to be flashed above, check if the camera is mounted correctly and working, by opening a terminal and execute the following to make sure the file exists:

    ls /dev/video0

    Note: the Jetson board supported both MIPI-CSI & USB cameras. The MIPI-CSI, (Mobile Industry Processor Interface - Camera Serial Interface), is for high speed transmission between cameras and host devices, straight to the processor, unlike USB stack with a lot of overhead. For more detailed information, see Jetson Nano + Raspberry Pi Camera. The Pi-camera is connected to CSI interface. The USB camera will be discussed in the future.

  • Check camera streaming - Note that decode, vic and display functionality can be accessed from software using the associated gstreamer plugins available as part of the GStreamer version 1.0 based accelerated solution in L4T. See Github for how to configure gst-launch-1.0

    gst-launch-1.0 nvarguscamerasrc \
! 'video/x-raw(memory:NVMM),width=3820, height=2464, framerate=21/1, format=NV12' \
! nvvidconv flip-method=2 \
! 'video/x-raw,width=960, height=616' \
! nvvidconv ! nvegltransform ! nveglglessink -e

  • Finally, update the Jetson Nano to get the latest OS patches

    sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get dist-upgrade

  • Now your Jetson Nano host is ready for AI applications

Deploy AI Application

Next, let’s install and setup an AI application to demonstrate DEC Potala in action. Let’s go to AI Solutions.
